bb

Evolutionary quantitative genetics

Mar 16, 2019

  • Why EQG?
  • Quantitative theory vs. qualitative
  • Evolution as descent with modification $\rightarrow$ genetics (theory of transmission)
  • evolutionary biology $\subset$ genetics $\subset$ biology (reductive canonical view, first is definitely no true)
  • Selection is on phenotype, transmission is of genotype
  • Genotype - phenotype ‘map’ is complex
  • Statistical approach analogous to statistical physics (systems of many particles are to complex (complicated?) to describe in ‘mechanistic’ terms (crazy systems of couple DEs probably). No physicist would embark on the mission full of needless suffering to describe such a system in terms of the exact particle mechanics. Indeed, we should not want to do that, as it arguably would not give much insight in the system ubject to our observations.
  • This is even more relevant for genetic and evolution. Dreaming of an ‘exact’ picture of the genotype-phenotype map is hopelessly vain for all but the simplest, special, and artificial biological systems. A theoretical description and investigation in terms of statistics is more desirable.
  • The trait of traits, lifetime fitness, can of course be regarded as such a complex quantitative trait.
  • A ‘true’ evolutionary systems biology, perhaps inspired on more ‘radical’ biological theory (e.g. Rosen or Rachevsky’s relational biology), could also be intersting, but I don’t see it happening.
  • So EQG naturally!
  • But it’s so boring?
  • But it’s so hard?
  • But it’s so archaic?

Consider a population with a quantitative trait $z$. We can try to think about the distribution over trait values $p(z)$.

Where $\Xi$ is the space of all possible genotypes, which is such a hopeless combinatorial mess that it is denoted by the most pedantic of greek letters, capital xi. In an ideal world, the first density $p(z|\xi)$ is determined by a comprehensive ‘genotype - phenotype map’, containing all sources of ‘phenotypic plasticity’ and so-called ‘genotype $\times$ environment interactions’.

As a first restriction, we might wish to consider the distribution over trait values conditional on a particular macro-evironment $E$

If we start thinking about transmission, we are in fact considering conditional ditributions, i.e. $p(z’|z)$. Characterizing this density to the level of detail required in a particular setting could perhaps be regarded as the core problem in EQG.

Thinking about expectations instead of densities, conditional expectations bring us in the sphere of regressions, which form the mathematical core of classical quantitative genetics.
